on r tibbetts wrote:
> > I agree that it looks idiotic, but the behavior th=
at the OP is
seeing is 
> > exactly how JUnit 3.8.1 has always worked /for =
assertions of 
> > primitives/. Look at the source of the junit.framework.A=
ssert
class. All 
> > of the assert*()s that compare primitives ultimately =
call fail(),
with a 
> > null message argument if no message was used as th=
e first argument to 
> > assert*(). This is the 'null' that you see in the =
test result
printout. 
> > Is this horrible user feedback? Yes. Note that t=
he assertions for 
> > Strings and Objects, instead of calling fail(), thro=
w a 
> > ComparisonFailure object. This is an extension of
AssertionFailedE=
rror 
> > that crafts an exception message string that's a bit more
user-fr=
iendly 
> > (i.e. the infamous "expected <....> but was <...>" message).
> =
>
> > IIRC, the junit-addons package 
> > (http://sourceforge.net/projects/=
junit-addons) has an alternative
Assert 
> > class that prints out much nic=
er exception messages.
> >
> >   
> >> I've never heard of such behaviour. =
What version of JUnit are you
using?

> >> Stephen Smith, MEng (Wale=
s).

et an error
